title: Kids, Pets, Your Allergies, and Theirs

content: It’s not easy managing seasonal allergies . Living with kids and pets can add an extra layer to your seasonal allergy management. For starters, certain factors related to having pets and children might worsen your allergies. And, they (yes, your pets, too!) might develop seasonal allergies themselves that you’ll need to help manage. Here’s everything you need to know to help you navigate allergy season with kids and pets in tow.

content_blocks.text: It’s not easy managing seasonal allergies . Living with kids and pets can add an extra layer to your seasonal allergy management. For starters, certain factors related to having pets and children might worsen your allergies. And, they (yes, your pets, too!) might develop seasonal allergies themselves that you’ll need to help manage. Here’s everything you need to know to help you navigate allergy season with kids and pets in tow.

sections.heading: How Children and Pets Affect Your Seasonal Allergies
content: When you have seasonal allergies, a key part of your allergy management is to limit how often you’re around certain allergens, like pollen and mold. When you add kids and pets to the mix, you’ve now got even more factors for tracking allergens into the house. You not only have to worry about whether you shook off all the pollen before you came inside; you’ve got to make sure your kids and your pets did, too. And that’s not all. Of course, you won’t develop an allergy to your children, but people with seasonal allergies are more likely than others to have pet allergies, too. It’s pretty likely that not only will the pollen on your dog’s or cat’s fur make you sneeze, but your furry friend’s coat itself may prompt a string of achoos as well.

content_blocks.text: When you have seasonal allergies, a key part of your allergy management is to limit how often you’re around certain allergens, like pollen and mold. When you add kids and pets to the mix, you’ve now got even more factors for tracking allergens into the house. You not only have to worry about whether you shook off all the pollen before you came inside; you’ve got to make sure your kids and your pets did, too. And that’s not all. Of course, you won’t develop an allergy to your children, but people with seasonal allergies are more likely than others to have pet allergies, too. It’s pretty likely that not only will the pollen on your dog’s or cat’s fur make you sneeze, but your furry friend’s coat itself may prompt a string of achoos as well.

sections.heading: Leave It Outside
content: During allergy season, your babies and fur babies will need to follow the same rules you likely follow when they come in from outdoors so that outdoor allergens stay where they belong. Before kids come in You can put a few simple household rules in place to help reduce allergen levels inside your home. Before your kids come in, have them: Take off their shoes and leave them outside or in an entryway. Remove their top layer of clothing and leave it outside or put it in a bag and take it straight to the washing machine. Head straight to the tub or shower if they’ve been playing hard and likely have pollen in their hair and on their skin .

content: If your children are so small that you need to do these things for them, it might be a good idea to hand this task off to another family member or wear a mask for the job just as you would when vacuuming or dusting.

content_blocks.text: If your children are so small that you need to do these things for them, it might be a good idea to hand this task off to another family member or wear a mask for the job just as you would when vacuuming or dusting.

sections.heading: Before pets come in
content: Before you let your pets back in after roaming outdoors, wipe them down, including the bottoms of their paws, with a pet wipe or a towel. Toss the towel in the washing machine right away. You might also find that it helps to bathe your dog a little more often than usual during allergy season. If you can’t get someone else to do it, you might want to wear a mask for this job.

content_blocks.text: Before you let your pets back in after roaming outdoors, wipe them down, including the bottoms of their paws, with a pet wipe or a towel. Toss the towel in the washing machine right away. You might also find that it helps to bathe your dog a little more often than usual during allergy season. If you can’t get someone else to do it, you might want to wear a mask for this job.

sections.heading: If You Have Pet Allergies, Too
content: If you live with pets and you have seasonal allergies, it might be hard to tell whether you’re also allergic to your pets. Who’s to say what exactly it was that caused your eyes to itch or your nose to start running. But people with seasonal allergies are more likely to have pet allergies, too. And if you continue to have allergy symptoms outside of the typical allergy season, that might be a sign that your furry friends are among your triggers.

content_blocks.text: If you live with pets and you have seasonal allergies, it might be hard to tell whether you’re also allergic to your pets. Who’s to say what exactly it was that caused your eyes to itch or your nose to start running. But people with seasonal allergies are more likely to have pet allergies, too. And if you continue to have allergy symptoms outside of the typical allergy season, that might be a sign that your furry friends are among your triggers.

content: You may want to get tested to find out whether Whiskers is part of the problem. That way, you can take the extra steps to keep your exposure (how often you’re around something) to pet allergens to a minimum. Here are some things you might do to limit allergic reactions to your pets: Keep the bedrooms of those who have allergies 100% pet-free. Keep pets off of fabric furniture and carpets as much as possible. Keep them only on surfaces that can be wiped or swept clean. Sweep, dust, or vacuum pet areas often. Wear a mask to do this job or ask someone else to complete it. Leave the pet grooming to someone else and have them do it outside. Have pets bathed at least once a week. Even cats can get used to it. If you must do the pet grooming yourself, wear a mask. Wash your hands and face after you pet your dog or cat when you can’t change clothes and shower entirely.

sections.heading: When Your Kids Inherit Your Allergies
content: If you’ve got seasonal allergies, your kids will likely have them, too. Allergies have a strong hereditary component, meaning they’re often passed down from parents to kids. Talk to your child’s pediatrician about symptoms. The doctor might diagnose the allergies and prescribe medication or refer you to an allergist for more in-depth testing. The doctor may recommend over-the-counter or prescription medication to relieve seasonal allergy symptoms. Besides the treatment your child’s doctor prescribes, your son or daughter will surely benefit from all the strategies you already have in place for yourself, such as washing your hands after petting the dog and leaving pollen-covered clothes outside the door.

content_blocks.text: If you’ve got seasonal allergies, your kids will likely have them, too. Allergies have a strong hereditary component, meaning they’re often passed down from parents to kids. Talk to your child’s pediatrician about symptoms. The doctor might diagnose the allergies and prescribe medication or refer you to an allergist for more in-depth testing. The doctor may recommend over-the-counter or prescription medication to relieve seasonal allergy symptoms. Besides the treatment your child’s doctor prescribes, your son or daughter will surely benefit from all the strategies you already have in place for yourself, such as washing your hands after petting the dog and leaving pollen-covered clothes outside the door.

sections.heading: Even Fido Can Be Allergic
content: When you see your pets scratching, it may not be fleas . Believe it or not, cats and dogs can get seasonal allergies, too.

content_blocks.text: When you see your pets scratching, it may not be fleas . Believe it or not, cats and dogs can get seasonal allergies, too.

sections.heading: What Do Seasonal Allergies Look Like in Pets?
content: Unlike humans, pets don’t usually sneeze in response to allergens. Instead, they scratch. Animals don’t typically have a lot of self-control when it comes to itching. They might scratch until they break their skin. Then scabs and bald spots will form.

content_blocks.text: Unlike humans, pets don’t usually sneeze in response to allergens. Instead, they scratch. Animals don’t typically have a lot of self-control when it comes to itching. They might scratch until they break their skin. Then scabs and bald spots will form.

content: In a pet with seasonal allergies, you might also see: Red, inflamed, or infected skin More shedding than usual More paw licking than usual (dogs) Scooting on or licking their bottom Red, waxy ears (especially in dogs that are already ear-infection prone) Difficulty breathing, coughing , or wheezing (cats) If your dog or cat seems to be scratching a lot, as in several times a day, or if you see any of these other symptoms, take them to the vet to get checked out. Itching can be a symptom of a number of different problems. The veterinarian may need to take skin scrapings to test your pet for allergies.

content_blocks.text: In a pet with seasonal allergies, you might also see: Red, inflamed, or infected skin More shedding than usual More paw licking than usual (dogs) Scooting on or licking their bottom Red, waxy ears (especially in dogs that are already ear-infection prone) Difficulty breathing, coughing , or wheezing (cats) If your dog or cat seems to be scratching a lot, as in several times a day, or if you see any of these other symptoms, take them to the vet to get checked out. Itching can be a symptom of a number of different problems. The veterinarian may need to take skin scrapings to test your pet for allergies.

sections.heading: How Do You Treat Allergies in Pets?
content: Your veterinarian may teach you how to safely give your pets over-the-counter allergy meds made for people. Here are some other ways to get relief. Bathe them often Use an oatmeal-based soap made for pets. Oatmeal soothes itching and moisturizers dry, irritated skin. Cats and dogs have a different pH balance than people, so soaps made for people might irritate their already-inflamed skin.

sections.heading: Wipe them down when they come in
content: Use pet-friendly wipes (again, people wipes might irritate) or a clean towel to wipe down paws and their entire coat after each time they come indoors. Limit outdoor time when pollen is high Just as you probably stay indoors when pollen counts are high, do what you can to keep your pets indoors, too. Pollen counts tend to be lowest in the late afternoon and evening. Plan walks and visits to the dog park for these lower-pollen times. Try omega-3 fatty acids Ask your veterinarian about giving your dog these oil supplements. They can relieve itching and, as an added bonus, soften your pet’s coat. Try local honey This tip is for dogs only. There are theories that because local honey contains local pollen, it can work almost like a vaccine for people and dogs. The evidence for this isn’t extremely solid, but it’s safe to give your dog honey as a sweet treat, so there’s no harm in trying.

sources: Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America: “Pet Allergy.”
meta_description: Kids and pets can track in all sorts of seasonal allergy triggers. Here’s what you can do to keep your symptoms and theirs at bay.
